content.description:
Advertisement for Madam C.J. Walker Products, 1906–1950

The document is a full-page newspaper advertisement featuring the following:

Portraits of 3 Black women

A photograph of a large brick building

Photographs of products

Text of varying size

The largest text in the advertisement reads as follows:

From A Slave Cabin to Riches and a Benefactress to Her Race

The Spirit of Mme. C.J. Walker Still Lives as is Evidenced in the Conclusion of Her Life’s Fondest Dreams

Who hasn’t heard of Madam C.J. Walker?

And Now this great, new building by and for our people!

Add Beauty to Brains for Success!

Be the Walker Type, The Way to Beauty and Success

Mme. C.J. Walker’s Preparations – Made By Colored People – For Colored People

Sold by Good Druggists and Walker Agents Everywhere

The Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of A’Lelia Bundles / Madam Walker Family Archives
content.question: Which of the following describes a legacy of Black-owned businesses in the twentieth century?

choices.label: They continue to operate as the main contributors to African American economic opportunities.
They are limited to specific types of businesses that cater to community needs.
They contribute to the growth of the American economy by providing jobs and giving back to their communities.
They were less popular at the end of the century due to increased urbanization in the United States.

content.answer: They contribute to the growth of the American economy by providing jobs and giving back to their communities.
